title: Tuesday, 9th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
GBKrona Hola
11:01 am
BE11:02am

Morning! Hello, welcome, hi.

MnM On time today!
BE11:02am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's this thing.

Mouselet Good morning people
BE11:03am

Seems Paul's doing one of his super-important editorial meeting things right now, which is apparently much more important than talking to you, dear reader.

Soundbuy Morning
Mouselet Some day I expect there might be a prime minister who could offer the managerial skills to, eg, get a group of drunken sailors laid on the Reeperbahn, but this is not that day
sneakyninja morning everyone. I am a newbie here, so hopefully won't say anything wrong just yet
FATDAZ we know our place
Mouselet good morning! do not fear error, error is a good way to learn interesting things
FATDAZ @sneakyninja welcome
AAAA bonjour les amis !
11:04 am
BE11:04am

The compensation is that I get to pick the portrait of the day, which means I can ignore business and politics and junk like that to focus instead on what's important.

BE11:04am

FATDAZ Morning all
BE11:05am

That, on the right, is Arthur Woodham of Arthur’s Cafe in Kingsland Road.

11:05 am

He gets an excellent write-up from the peerless Spitalfields Life blog, which I highly recommend: http://spitalfield...r-of-arthurs-cafe/

BE11:06am

See also this 2016 review of Arthur's from Marina, which sums the place up better than I can: https://www.thegua...-restaurant-review

Mouselet and I wonder what happened to Severn Trent
FATDAZ @BE re the blog I am pleased to find I am not the only follower :)

BE11:07am

Do go along to pay your respects and/or order a Tottenham cake. 495 Kingsland Rd.

undefined

(@Fatdaz: here's my favourite Spitalfields Life post. See if you can spot why: http://spitalfield...carney-machinist/)

Anyway .... I guess we should kick on with the day job.

BE11:10am

Which is supermarkets, in the main.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 230.60, up 3.7 (+1.63%), High: 237.80, Low: 229.90, Volume: 11.09m
gh Down with Paul Murphy!

Pharma Being "peerless" seems to be the main qualification for appearing as a guest publication on Have I Got News for You (but I am sure it is a fascinating read)
11:10 am
BE11:11am

Rather mixed signals this morning. Kantar data versus Morrison numbers.

BE11:12am

We'll start with the former. Market growth up to 5.3%, from 3.1% in the prior period, but that's mostly just a calendar effect.

FATDAZ @Pharma it documents the dramatic and ongoing changes a section of the east end of London and the laments the passing of the old guard
Mouselet fatdaz: that is for some reason the wrong link. carney-machinist features a guest appearance by Kweku Adoboli
FATDAZ to a section
Mouselet and Dan Cruickshank

The main news is that Tesco seems to be losing market share and Asda isn't. As in, no share loss for the first time in 3 years.

Mouselet http://spitalfieldslife.com/2010/03/19/linda-carney-machinist/ without the bracket at the end makes the link link
11:13 am
BE11:13am

As per Goldman.

BE11:13am

Tesco: after two very strong months, Tesco returned to market share losses of c.40bp, in line with September 2017. Although the quarter still shows it growing more strongly than Big 4 peers, the coincidence of these share losses and Asda’s best market share performance since 2014 is something we need to watch.

Digi Master Morning all
BE11:14am

(@Mouselet: thank you. I appoint you my official translator.)

Mouselet (why the link links to somewhere else if you add the bracket is undeniably a question)
11:14 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 211.60, down 2.7 (-1.26%), High: 217.10, Low: 209.70, Volume: 11.21m
red what stands out is continued large gains by the germans
BE11:15am

And Jefferies.

BE11:15am

Calendar impact flatters momentum, underlying consumer still soft... as Kantar reported for the 4wks to 31 Dec 2017 vs 1 Jan 2017. As a result, overall industry sales growth of 4.6% over that period was significantly flattered by the exclusion of the traditionally very slow trading of 1 Jan (and as a result relative, rather than absolute performance, informs our commentary). A further step up in discounters' growth over that period suggests that UK consumers remained, unsurprisingly, defensively minded. German players at this end of the market saw sales growth of 18.1% (and c.32% on a 2yr stack basis, the strongest showing of 2017). Both Waitrose (+4.1%) and M&S (+6%) also traded well, but the calendar shift would have been especially accretive to retailers at the higher end of the market.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

TSCO momentum appears to have inflected negatively as cash sales growth of 3.8% implies an inflection from strong outperformance in October and November (a time of significant promotional activity by the UK leader) to a lag to the other UK majors in December. Non-food performance was the strongest of the UK majors, but conversely grocery performance was not.

SBRY still lagging but food momentum improving as till roll growth of 3% split into 1.6% for non-food and 3.4% for food (the strongest 2017 print for SBRY). The shifting of a wine promotion later into December may have helped footfall trends (with a soft comp also a consideration).

MRW momentum has inflected positively with cash sales growth of 4.9% and grocery at 3.6% confirming the strong print of earlier today. The two-year stack is an impressive 9.3%.

ASDA the fastest growing UK major over Xmas with cash sales growing by 5.3% (and grocery impressive at +5.5%). However, this needs to be considered in the context of a soft comparison base (a dynamic that will progressively change in the months ahead).

red i think the changes in the big 4 can be put down to rounding errors. i think its difficult for them to make any inroads that are sustainable.
BE11:16am

@Red points out the discounters continuing to gain. Well, yes and no.

FATDAZ @mouselett thanks all become clear I walk past the soup kitchen most days
BE11:16am

Aldi and Lidl took 120 bp market share, but that's from 150 bp in the previous four weeks and 134 bp 2017 year to date.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Combined market share of 11.1%, against 12.4% prior period. Suggesting .... people don't care as much about hard discounts over Christmas, I guess?

FATDAZ @mous;ett in a different life I used to speak to KA little knowing what he would become
BE11:17am

Seems to me it's not a new trend, or a particularly significant one.

Penny re ARTHURS: comments on the Guardian piece are quite amusing re Dalston
BE11:18am

Here's Bruno at Bernstein.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Tesco 4 wk data not as strong compared to peers but sample too small to be meaningful. On 4 wk basis Tesco's till roll improved 80bps (3.8%). The market seems to make something out of the fact that other supermarkets did better on the 4-wk measure. The 4-wk data is a reasonable measure for TSCO (given its size), but for the smaller retailers it is total statistical noise (explaining why consensus had its MRW Xmas forecast wrong). A nice trading opportunity for those wanting to buy the dip before Tesco's trading statement on Thursday. We increase our forecast for Tesco UK Christmas LfL from +2.5% to +2.9%.

BE11:19am

But anyway, back to Morrison.

FATDAZ re the Supermarkets and this is purely anecdotal I have noticed in our area that empty shelves are not uncommon whether that means a loosening in Just in time supply chains to save money remains to be seen but thats my hunch

Sales beat, easily.

doeswalk @FATDAZ or full employment means they can't find anyone to fill them
red @FATDAZ i was in uk over xmas and noticed that too, not just food stores but many other areas such as toys diy. only one or two items at best on show, the area behind empty.
11:21 am

Retail alone +2.1% vs consensus +1.3%

This is clearly a very strong set of figures – we await the release of market share data at 8am today to better understand whether Morrison has done exceptionally strongly or whether the wider market has been very strong (NB the Kantar data will likely flatter industry growth as New Year’s Day – typically a very quiet day – will be absent from the data, whereas it was included last year).

BE11:24am

Morrison trades on a 2018E PE of 18.3x versus Sainsbury on 11.8x and the European sector average of 15.3x.

BE11:26am

Despite this better-than–expected sales performance, the group stated that its 2017-18 expectations are unchanged. We think this is due to ongoing robust cost inflation and do not anticipate any significant change in consensus expectations. At this stage, we see no reason to change our cautious view (demanding valuation ratios, disappointing margin trend in 2017-18e vs last year)

BE11:26am

(@Fatdaz: 10% sales growth, which probably suggests some market share wins, though hard to judge in isolation.)

FATDAZ @Penny not the worst position to be in

Incidentally, since we've only got Morrison and Kantar and Nielsen figures on the supermarkets this morning, Exane has decided to chuck out some more data.

FATDAZ @BE thanks VM
hornblower anything on Topps, 3 mths LFL +3%
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Regular survey of 3k branded and own-label grocery items across the big four, plus Waitrose and Ocado.

BE11:28am

Along with an "essentials" bag of 30 items.

BE11:29am

According to our Brandview compiled data, inflation was at 1.9% in January vs 3.0% last month. This slowdown is largely explained by the less deflationary base we think (-0.9% in January 2017 vs -2.8% in December 2016). Taking a look at retailers, Tesco continued to be the most inflationary in the period (+4.7%) while inflation was a lot more subdued for the rest of the Big 4 (Morrisons especially – see below). For the first time in more than a year, inflation was driven more by branded products (+2.3%) than by own-label products (+1.2%). On a month-to-month basis, prices rose by 4.4% after two months of deflationary trends.

RA has anyone else seen the NVidia highlights from CES yesterday? some serious technology being produced.
11:29 am
BE11:29am

In our narrower key items price study, the key takeaway was that Aldi and ASDA adopted a deflationary pricing strategy while other retailers increased their prices. As a result, the price gap of the Big 4 vs Aldi increased during the period to 21% (vs 14% last month).

BE11:30am

So ....... looks like Morrison winning on volume growth, Tesco most efficient at passing through inflation.

We are updating estimates to reflect November’s interim results. Headline numbers and target price are not changing significantly but the balance of the P&L alters to reflect sales growth at lower margins as the group responds to pet food price competition, particularly in the online space. We expect similar trends when the group issues its Q3 update on January 23. Our brief pricing survey indicates that branded pet food prices at the online pure plays continue to fall and are lower than at Pets At Home, suggesting margin stabilisation is still some way off.

chad_john KAZ going guns blazing today.

BE11:34am

Dog food price tracker: We performed a brief analysis of Pets At Home’s food price positioning relative to a number of online and multichannel competitors in November that we updated in January. On well known branded dog foods Pets At Home looks price competitive relative to multichannel chains Pets Corner and Jollyes but at a premium to some of the online pure plays including Amazon, Ocado’s Fetch and Petplanet. Average prices in our survey falling 2-3% over the two-month period suggests the market remains highly competitive. Pets At Home's own brand dog food continues to be c.10% cheaper than similar branded products.

BE11:40am

On the Neuro spin, our impression was that the company plan to strengthen the investment thesis through boltons in 2018, before a likely spin in 2019. This could improve the potential value the market would ascribe to a potential spun-off Neuro business, though it would also slow the pace of deleveraging, with the deleveraging guidance issued yesterday (ND/EBITDA less than 2.5x for end ‘18), being ex any business development activities. On 2018/19 Pushes and Pulls, the 2018/19 Gross margin headwind as a result of the new Covington manufacturing plant opening was noted, though this could presumably at least partly be offset by the manufacturing cost saving program announced with Q3 results.

Shinshin So we're saying that pet food branding is a bit of a dog's dinner ?
BE11:40am

The company also reiterated the previously issued medium-term tax rate guidance of 16-18%, post recent US tax reform, which appears to rule out significant earnings downside around increased taxes on US profits due to the BEAT (Base Erosion Anti-Abuse Tax) provision. That said, if Shire’s tax rate were to end up at the upper end of this guidance range, this would still equate to a c.2.1% trim vs. consensus tax rate expectations for the company to maintain a 16.2% tax rate, or a 1.0% hit at the mid-point.

red i would say avoid the cheapest stuff as its really not good what goes in it
BE11:41am

Overall, we see yesterday’s share-price underperformance around the business update as excessive, and we continue to see Shire offering compelling value, particularly from a SOP approach.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

However the stock also continues to offer limited near-term catalysts in 2018, and we still see the potential for some slight negative earnings momentum, at least vs. sellside consensus forecasts. We also believe the updated 2020 guidance issued yesterday, for Revenues of $17-18bn could still prove a touch optimistic, vs. JPMe of $16.2bn, assuming significant Haemophilia erosion, and not including any contribution from future business development.

We had previously noted that we believed Shire had already
given up on its 2020 guidance but also noted that given the anticipated competition in haemophilia, Shire may need to consider writing down the carrying value of some of the Baxalta acquisition. Now that it has officially reduced its 2020 guidance, investors should rationally question whether a partial Baxalta write-down may be next

11:44 am

Not a surprise, but the reduction will do Shire’s credibility no favours. Although the reduction in 2020 revenue guidance should not come as a major surprise, the fact that it has occurred at all (especially in light of some vocal opposition at the time to doing the USD32bn Baxalta deal), will do Shire’s credibility no favours, in our view. Shire now has two pivotal events in 2018: the Haven-4 data with competitor drug Hemlibra (mid-year) and a decision on its corporate structure (H2)

11:47 am
BE11:48am

OFWAT published their 2019 Price Review (“PR19”) methodology in December. The indicative allowed cost of capital for 2020/1 to 2024/5 is 2.4% real on an RPI-indexed basis. Down from 3.7-3.8% in the current review (“PR14”). This looks tough and raises the risk of dividend cuts, particularly at United Utilities. Pennon has growth from Viridor, while Severn Trent will have built a buffer of deferred income from its sewer flooding ODIs that will mitigate the dividend pressure.

BE11:48am

With OFWAT’s proposed tough allowed return, we no longer think that any premium to RAB is warranted (we had previously assumed a 10% premium). Resetting & partially indexing the cost of debt will also make financial outperformance less valuable. We are lowering our price targets to reflect this. Pennon price target drops to 900p (was 950p) Severn Trent to 1950p (was 2150p) and United Utilities to 800p (was 1000p). Severn Trent now has 9% downside and we have lowered our rating to Underperform.

BE11:52am

Despite some triumphalism, Labour lost the 2017 General Election and, arguably, going into 2018 the Conservative government now looks relatively more stable, given the stage 1 deal on Brexit. (although, of course, a week is a long time in politics). Nevertheless, we think investors may be underestimating the difficulties of nationalising the English water companies, with Labour looking very unlikely to achieve the majority of English MPs needed to pass the legislation.

BE11:52am

As for the power utilities .... hang on .....

BE11:53am

Our economists expect a less benign macro environment [than 2017], especially in H2. On the bright side costcutting remains a source of upside that can deliver 2-3% EPS growth p.a. for the industry as employee populations age. However, any bid to accelerate that could incur high upfront costs; in addition the automation/digitisation of processes is not without its pitfalls for a slow-moving, capexled industry. With higher commodity prices now in consensus numbers, a further price recovery is needed to drive earnings upgrades. We draw comparisons to the last industry M&A cycle and show that portfolio reorganisations rather than large scale M&A are more likely. We also show that the energy system problems that batteries are called on to solve might be simpler than expected.

And SIG, interestingly. Here's Clyde Lewis's notes on them.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Last year saw the three senior board members (Chairman, CEO and CFO) being replaced following another period when the group promised a lot but failed to deliver. The new team (Andrew Allner – Chairman, Meinie Oldersma – CEO, Nick Maddock – CFO) has got off to a good start with some debt reduction, disposals and other cost cutting measures being enacted. As a result the shares bounced sharply in 2017 (+71%) and no longer look cheap relative to the peer group on current forecasts. However, forecasts look to be conservatively cut which is understandable given the historical poor performance of the group. Margin analysis of some of its main peers though points to more material upside which would make the current ratings of c14.2x PE and 8.3x EV/EBITDA and 0.39x EV/Sales for 2018 look far too low.

BE12:09pm

Here's another one that caught my eye.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

Gulf Keystone# (Buy, TP 270p) holds a material operated interested in a world-class, low-cost, onshore and low-geological risk producing oil field in Kurdistan (PHe FY18 23Mbbl/d working interest production subject to investment). In our view, uncertainty surrounding ratification of amendments to its PSC is weighing on the value of the business currently being attributed by the market. There are many oil majors/SOE’s/mid-size independents that owing the recent downturn and postponement of investment decisions are facing increasing pressure to address the issue of reserve replacement. Dependent on ratification of the amended PSC terms, we think Gulf Keystone could represent a smart acquisition to a larger player that is looking to secure new supply of oil production that offers multi-decade visibility on production cash flows.

Revolution Bars, as mentioned several times yesterday ...

BE12:15pm

The company has no CEO, no LFL momentum, a very low
valuation of just 3.3x site level EV/EBITDA with a central cost base that is disproportionately high. The obvious deal is an all equity merger with the high-flying Deltic Group (which recently posted a 9% increase in LFL sales), resolving RBG’s management issues and enabling synergies to be retained by the current shareholders. The Chairman’s reluctance to engage should eventually succumb to pressure to create value for shareholders, of which Deltic is one.

And Merlin Entertainments, which seems to be an idea that's gathering some interest. As in: would Merlin be better if broken up and debted to the eyeballs?

BE12:16pm

We have been surprised by the de-rating of Merlin. The impact of terrorism on demand in the key UK markets has been material but we expect a steady recovery consistent with improvements in other markets after demand shocks. The Group has an established pipeline of development opportunities, which will increase the geographical diversification of the business and is a clear beneficiary of the trend for increased tourism. Demand for Lego toys softened notably in 2017 after several years of remarkable growth, and this had an effect on retail sales. We expect the new Lego movie to revive interest in the product and for demand for the child-friendly theme parks to remain robust. This is a highly cash-generative global business and we expect it to attract bid interest at the current level.
